abstract.text: Objectives: The purpose of this study was to define and delineate specific nontechnical 2 competencies for first-line public health responders in Chemical, Biological, Radiological and 3 Nuclear (CBRN) emergencies in China. 4 Study design: A qualitative study was conducted in China involving interviews with key 5 informants in the field of health response to CBRN disasters. 6 Methods: One-on-one in-depth interviews were carried out with 20 participants, including 7 expert members of National Medical Response Teams for CBRN Disasters, officials at 8 emergency management authorities, and scholars of academic institutions related to CBRN 9 emergency. Interviews were recorded with audio equipment, transcribed and coded into 10 codable passages according to grounded theory with NVivo software. Themes were identified 11 within the transcriptions by using thematic analysis.

12 Results: 159 codable passages were produced. Eight domains of nontechnical core 13 competencies were identified: (1) situation awareness, (2) communication skills, (3) 14 collaboration, (4) resource management, (5) task management, (6) cultural competency, (7) 15 austere environment skills, and (8) physical stamina. 16 Conclusions: The study identified a variety of competencies for on-scene public health 17 responders in CBRN emergencies. The findings of this study could specifically benefit 18 development of strategy and improvement of content of education and training. Further 19 research that involves input from the disaster response community at large are needed for the 20 validation of these competencies. 21 KEY WORDS: Nontechnical Competencies, Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear 22 Response, Disaster Medicine, Health Personnel Education/Training.

There are specific requirements in nontechnical 210 competencies for public health responders in CBRN events besides some common 211 competencies. Those identified competencies could be useful to develop a workforce for 212 CBRN emergencies, such as outlining competency-based training and updating job 213 description for recruitment. The proposed competency framework can be used to support 214 developers of public health emergency preparedness training initiatives by ensuring that 215 public health professionals are able to demonstrate the non-technical knowledge and skills 216 10 needed for successful performance when preparing and responding to CBRN incidents. It can 217 also help update and revise job descriptions, and orient public health practitioners to their 218 emergency roles and responsibilities. The changing practical context and requirements for 219 CBRN responses in the future demands the constant updating and redefining of the 220 competency framework. 221 DECLARATIONS 222 Ethical Considerations 223 This project was approved by the Ethics Committee of (author organization). CBRN events have an additional "fear-factor" and expose responders in potential 55 agents and possible hazard, and it has been reported that health professionals may not respond 56 to CBRN events as willingly as they would to a conventional disaster event 25-27 .

There are differences in particular context and nature among various disasters, so it is difficult 58 to define a consistent set of competencies across disciplines and jurisdictions. The present 59 study aims to define and identify specifically nontechnical competencies for on-scene public 60 health workers in CBRN disasters. This study employed a constructivist grounded theory approach encompassing the notion that 81 interpretation of the data is co-constructed by interactions between participants and 82 researchers. According to grounded theory, analysis occurred alongside data collection and 83 was able to inform the next interview and develop an emergent understanding of the themes 84 and findings. Substantive coding facilitated the process of theoretical sampling and directed 85 the evolution of the interview guide. As interviews were conducted and coded, the 86 competencies were revised iteratively. Theoretical sampling was done until the researchers 87 reached theoretical saturation. That is to say, when conducting more interviews would add 88 little value to the research, and data saturation was achieved, and the interviewing ceased.

China has experienced 200-600 accidents every year in hazardous 27 chemical industry 1 , frequent emerging epidemics 2 (e.g., COVID-19, SARS, H5N1 and 28 African Swine Flu), over 43 planned nuclear reactors 3 and unpredictable terrorism attacks. 29 China has invested heavily in the development of CBRN medical response capacity including 30 the CBRN Medical Response Teams (CBRN-MRT) designed to be deployed on the site. 31 In spite of the fact that public health responders adequately respond to the clinical or public 32 health aspects of disasters, they are not always prepared or trained to work in a real hazardous 33 environment and complex temporary situation 4 . The unique nature of intense working 34 relationships and particularly austere environment requires not only technical skills but also 35 nontechnical competencies. A body of previous studies have explored the components of 36 nontechnical competency for health workers in a critical environment 5-10 .It has been 37 established that interpersonal, social, and cognitive skills play an important role on the 38 response performance 11 . Those nontechnical competencies broadly involve a range of 39 knowledge, attitude, and skills in communication 12-14 , collaboration 15, 16 , leadership 17-19 , 40 situation awareness 12 , and other individual personal attributes 20 . However, the literature 41 search revealed relatively few studies specifically focusing on public health staff working at a 42 CBRN incident site.

The present study 130 developed 8 nontechnical core competencies specifically required for first-line public health 131 responders in CBRN emergencies. According to the similarities and differences in response 132 methods-between CBRN emergencies and other general disasters, those identified 133 competencies are discussed in three groups: common, enhanced and specialized nontechnical 134 competencies. 135 Common Nontechnical Competencies 136 The challenges posed and the response requirement for CBRN and accidental incidents differ, 137 but are similar or the same in many respects. For that reason, some of the competencies 138 explored within this study is equally applicable to both situations and can be implemented for 139 all levels of incident. Some components of nontechnical competencies identified through this 140 study thus confirmed correlations with the common skills defined in prior research involving 141 health professionals working in general critical situations, including communication 12-14, 17, 30 , 142 collaboration 15, 16, 31 , and cultural competencies 32 . Due to widespread public concern about 143 mass casualties and diverse participation of multiple professions, public health responders in CBRN incidents are required to do well in communicating internally and externally, along 145 with interprofessional and intra-agency collaboration within complex managerial structures 11, 146 13, 16, 26, 33 .Understanding of cultural background, ethical principles and regulations is also 147 necessary for CBRN public health responders to deal with common interest conflicts and 148 dilemmas 22 . In addition, this study added specific understanding of those common 149 competencies by description of corresponding sub-competencies that are required in the other disasters, emphasis and enhancement should be placed on the 153 competencies of situation awareness, resources management, and task management. CBRN 154 missions in contrast have often involved unknown or unidentified substances, with a greater 155 emphasis on the need to identify the substance through sampling and intelligence collection.

Task management not only 164 directly affects response performances, which has been widely cited in previous literature 8, 9 , 165 but it also may have indirect influence by affecting other nontechnical competencies. Most of 166 interviewees indicated that having a good knowledge of professional task procedures and 167 standards is a type of fundamental nontechnical competency that can make contributions to better communication, collaboration and mental quality. Most study participants started their discussions with 179 personal safety considerations and skills in a hot or warm zone, and psychological self-care 180 was also highlighted as essential for medical workers at high risk of suffering severe stress or 181 even anxiety disorders from the fear of CBRN hazards. In addition, overwhelming workloads 182 are frequently encountered by medical staff dressed in heavy PPE in austere hazardous 183 environments, where they encounter an influx of patients. In contrast to prior studies 9, 15, 19 , 184 physical stamina was frequently discussed in this study as a nontechnical competency that 185 makes a substantial contribution to response performance. qualitative study is subject to several limitations. The raw data were the expressed 189 opinions of a purposive sample of experts. While inclusion criteria for subjects was based on 190 their experience in the field of CBRN responses and their varying backgrounds, it is possible 191 that a potential source of bias in respondents exists. Secondly, the interpretivist framework raises questions about the validity of the findings and empirical generalizability of the study, 193 though validity checks on the coding and data analysis are allowed. Finally, this qualitative 194 study was intended to identify categories, not to quantify their relative importance to the 195 participants. 196 Further study should continue to identify and validate potential nontechnical competencies 197 using multiple approaches based a broader sample to explore the attributes of effective public 198 health responders in new CBRN emergencies. With the changing characteristics of CBRN 199 incidents, the competency framework should keep updating to match the emergent needs of 200 response and to advance the evolvement of workforce development processes. More efforts 201 are also needed to explore relative contribution of each nontechnical competency to the 202 comprehensive performance of public health responders, and relationship among those 203 competencies. TABREF0.text: Complicating a straightforward emergency response is the addition of CBRN factors which add an extra layer of complexity to the emergency response 21 . CBRN emergencies cause trauma on a large scale and demand complex responses including triage, monitoring, diagnosis, decontamination, and self-protection for public health workers 11, 22 . CBRN mass casualty situations are normally chaotic. Casualties may have single or multiple injuries, or may have conventional injuries which are complicated by CBRN exposure (such as in a toxic spill or nuclear power plant accident). The treatment of CBRN casualties should reflect the conventional incident and casualty management paradigms with additional safety and treatment considerations 23 .
